part2.question:
Describe a toy that you loved in your childhood. You should say:
What the toy was
Who gave it to you
How often you played with it
And explain why it was so special to you.
part2.model_answer: I'd like to describe a toy that I absolutely loved when I was a child. It was a remote-controlled car that my father gave me for my sixth birthday. I played with it almost every day after school in our small garden, racing it around obstacles I built. It was special because it was my Pride and joy [掌上明珠], and playing with it allowed me to be very Imaginative [富于想象的] creating complex race tracks and scenarios. Even now, simply thinking about it takes me on a pleasant Trip down memory lane [追忆往昔] and makes me feel quite Nostalgic [怀旧的] for those simple, carefree days of my youth.

part2.question:
Describe a game (indoor or outdoor) you played when you were a child. You should say:
What the game was
Who you played it with
Where you played it
And explain why you enjoyed it.
part2.model_answer: I vividly remember playing hide-and-seek with my cousins during long summer holidays. We played it in my grandmother's large backyard, which had plenty of great hiding spots like trees and bushes. It was a simple game, but we loved the thrill of Interaction [互动] and the friendly fun to find the best place where no one could see us. We had to be clever and quiet. I enjoyed it deeply because it was pure fun and allowed us to be creative with our strategies. Those moments are some of my most Precious [珍贵的] memories of childhood innocence.

part2.question:
Describe a toy or game that is popular with children today. You should say:
What it is
Why it is popular
Whether you think it is good for children
And explain how it compares to toys from your childhood.
part2.model_answer: LEGO sets are incredibly popular with children today all over the world. They are popular because they encourage Creativity [创造力] and allow kids to build anything they can imagine, from castles to spaceships. I think they are excellent Educational [有教育意义的] toys because they help with Cognitive [认知的] Development [发展] and complex problem-solving skills effectively. Compared to my simple wooden blocks from the past, modern LEGOs are much more detailed and colorful. However, both serve the same purpose of sparking a child's imagination and are Durable [耐用的] enough to last for years of active play. They are truly timeless.

part3.question: Do boys and girls prefer different kinds of toys?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Generally, yes, but gender stereotypes regarding toys are changing rapidly in modern society. [Reason] Traditionally, boys liked cars and action figures while girls preferred dolls and cooking sets. [Example] However, nowadays, many girls enjoy building sets and boys play with kitchen toys freely without judgment. [Extension] It is important to let children choose what they enjoy without forcing roles or rules.

part3.question: How do toys that were popular in the past compare with toys that are popular now?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Past toys were simpler and more Durable [耐用的], often made of wood or metal. [Reason] Modern toys are often electronic and plastic, focusing heavily on screens and flashing lights. [Example] While old toys encouraged physical play, new ones might be more Educational [有教育意义的] but sedentary in nature. [Extension] Both have their merits in fostering healthy Child's play [小儿科] habits.

part3.question: What should people consider when choosing a toy for a child?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Safety and Educational [有教育意义的] value are the most important factors to consider for parents. [Reason] A toy should be age-appropriate and not have small parts that are dangerous to swallow. [Example] Parents should also consider if it encourages Socialization [社会化] and positive Interaction [互动] with other kids. [Extension] A good toy stimulates the mind and body simultaneously.

part3.question: Should kids be permitted to pick their own toys at a toy store?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Yes, within reason, as it teaches decision-making and responsibility early on. [Reason] Letting them choose gives them a sense of autonomy and ownership over their play items. [Example] However, parents should guide them to avoid buying something just because it's expensive or trendy. [Extension] We shouldn't raise a Spoiled brat [被宠坏的孩子] who refuses to Play by the rules [遵守规则].

part3.question: Do educational toys really help children become smarter?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Yes, they can significantly aid Cognitive [认知的] Development [发展] and foster Creativity [创造力]. [Reason] Toys that require problem-solving or logic puzzles exercise the brain effectively like a muscle. [Example] Building blocks help with spatial awareness and math skills from a very young age. [Extension] They make learning fun rather than a boring chore for the child through healthy Competition [竞争].

part3.question: Is it harmful for children to own too many toys?
part3.model_answer: [Opinion] Owning too many toys can make children less Imaginative [富于想象的] and grateful for what they have. [Reason] When they have everything, they don't need to invent games or be creative with resources. [Example] A child with fewer toys often plays more deeply with each one they cherish. [Extension] We should not Wrap someone in cotton wool [过分保护] with excessive gifts that hurt the family Economy [经济 (cost of toys)].
